metadata.title: Porous and high electronic conductivity nitrogen-doped nano-sheet carbon derived from polypyrrole for high-power supercapacitors

sections.text:
M AN
US CR
AC CE
PT ED
Porous yet high electronic conductivity carbon electrodes with high ion-adsorptive surface area and low ion/charge transport resistance are crucial to the realization of high-energy/power supercapacitors but have proved to be very challenging to obtain. Herein, nitrogen-doped nano-sheet carbons were synthesized by direct carbonization and activation of polypyrrole at different temperatures. As the temperature increases from 500 to 900 ℃, the specific surface area increases from 187 m-2 g-1 to 1450 m-2 g-1 with abundant mesopore and the doping-nitrogen transfer to more stable donor doping state which can improve its electronic conductivity (up to 26.2 S cm-1). Symmetrical supercapacitors based on this carbon exhibit a high energy density of 45.0 Wh kg-1 at 260 W kg-1 and 22.3 Wh kg-1 as the power density increasing to 38.7 kW kg-1, as well as excellent long-term cycling stability, which can be ascribed to its high surface area for electrolyte ions adsorption, and abundant mesopore and high electronic conductivity for ion and electron fast transfer. The remarkable performances suggest that this carbon material is a promising candidate for high-power output supercapacitor electrode materials.
1. Introduction
* Corresponding author: Telephone/ Fax numbers: +86 29 82665161; E-mail address: ylxu@mail.xjtu.edu.cn.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
High performance energy storage devices are one of the most important elements for the future development of portable electronic devices, electrical vehicles and renewable energy [1]. Supercapacitors are promising devices with long life for highly efficiency electrochemical energy storage and high-power management. It has been demonstrated that the supercapacitor performances crucially depend on the physical and chemical properties of its electrode materials [2, 3]. Three electrodes are usually classified based on the charge storage mechanisms of the active material, i.e. electrochemical double layer capacitance (EDLC) electrodes, pseudo-capacitance electrodes and hybrid battery-like electrodes. EDLC electrodes mainly use carbon materials and store energy by the reversible electrostatic accumulation of ions at the electrode/electrolyte interface. Pseudo-capacitance electrodes are based on the fast and reversible redox reaction at the surface or near-surface of the active materials [4, 5]. For these electrodes, the charge depends on the change in potential, yielding a capacitance during the redox reaction process. Battery-like electrodes usually use traditional battery materials which can exhibit capacitance-like properties at nanoscale dimensions due to the fast ion intercalation and diffusion (usually is Li+) [4, 6]. According to the reports in recent years, conducting polymers [7, 8] and metal oxides [9] show great potential as the supercapacitors electrode material due to their large faraday pseudo-capacitance. Nevertheless, carbon based materials (about 80-120 F g-1 in organic electrolytes) are still the dominant electrode material for commercial supercapacitors because of their high electronic conductivity, low cost, long cycling life, suitability to various electrolyte systems including organic electrolytes, and higher stability (long-time and potential dependent) [3, 10]. In the past several decades, many kinds of carbon materials with large specific surface area which can provide more active interface for charge and/or ions adsorption have been extensively investigated as electrode materials to improve the capacitance, such as carbon nanospheres [11] carbon fiber [12], carbon onions [5, 13, 14], carbon nanotubes [15, 16], carbide-derived carbon (CDC) [17-19], and graphene [20]. Some work suggested that the specific surface area, pore size distribution, and electronic conductivity of porous carbon material strongly affected the supercapacitors electrochemical performance [21, 22]. To further improve the specific surface area and
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
porosity, some kinds of porous carbon with micropore and mesopore have been prepared by various methods such as template nano-carbons [23], 3D carbon network [24], novel carbide-derived carbon (CDC)[25, 26], and various ultra-porous activated carbons [27, 28]. Although most of porous carbon materials exhibit a large capacitance due to their large specific surface area, the electronic conductivity decreased with further increasing specific surface area and porosity due to non-compatibility of conductive pathways, which significantly limits the rate performance and power capability[12, 29].
To enhance the rate performance and power capability, doping of heteroatoms (such as nitrogen [30-32], sulfur [33], or boron [34]) into carbon frameworks is a vital candidate. Recent research indicates that nitrogen doping seems to be the most promising method for enhancing capacitance while keeping the superb cycling stability of carbon material. Moreover, it is discovered that the electronic conductivity can also be improved by nitrogen doping [32, 35]. To date, there are two common strategies utilized to incorporate nitrogen atoms into carbon materials: (1) post treatment of the porous carbon with nitrogen rich reagents such as urea [36], ammonia [37], and nitrogen gas [38]; (2) in situ doping by carbonizing nitrogen-rich synthetic polymers or organic carbon precursors [11, 12, 39-41], such as polyacrylonitrile [39], formaldehyde resins [40], and egg white [41]. The main effect of N-doping is enhancing the surface wettability, electronic conductivity and pseudo-capacitance which crucially depend on the nitrogen content in carbon material. The post treatment processing of the porous carbon generally results in a low content of nitrogen [42]. The second strategy might be a promising way for easy and controllable synthesizing of nitrogen-rich carbon materials. However, the nonporous or low surface area of these N-rich carbons leads to low electrochemical double layer capacitance, which is the main way to store energy in carbon materials. Therefore, nitrogen-doped carbon with high surface area and porosity is desirable for electrochemical capacitive energy storage with high capacitance, excellent rate performance and power capability.
Herein, we report the synthesis of nitrogen-doped nano-sheet carbons (NCs) from polypyrrole (PPy) by carbonization and chemical activation with KOH as activation agent. Nano-sheet PPy has been selected as
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
synthetic precursor due to its large specific surface area and high percentage of the carbonaceous residue left after thermal treatment. We find that carbonization temperature plays a critical role in determining the physical and chemical properties of the NCs such as specific surface area and porosity, graphitization, the nitrogen content and N-Q species which can greatly improve the electronic conductivity. Electrochemical testing results indicate that the fabricated supercapacitors exhibit a high specific capacitance (192 F g-1 at 0.5 A g-1), excellent cycling stability (91.9% initial capacitance retention after 20000 cycles and 79.7% after 75000 cycles at 5 A g-1), high energy density (45.0 Wh kg-1) and large power density (up to 38.7 kW kg-1).

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials synthesis
sections.text:
Pyrrole from Capchem (99.8%) was distilled prior to use. All other reagents were analytical grade and commercially available from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. and used as received without further purification. The detailed synthesis procedures of carbonaceous PPy precursor were reported elsewhere [8]. Then, the dry PPy precursor was carbonized and activated by heating (with a ramp 2 ℃ min-1) the
KOH/PPy mixture (KOH/PPy weight ratio of 1) under nitrogen to a final temperature of 500, 600, 700, 800, 900 ℃ for 1 h. The obtained NCs were thoroughly washed with HCl (0.1 mol L-1) to remove any
inorganic salts and then washed with distilled water until neutral pH and finally dried in an oven (80 ℃).
Therefore, we have prepared a series of disordered porous N-doped carbon material by carbonization and activation at different temperatures, which were named as NC-500, NC-600, NC-700, NC-800, and NC-900, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2. Chemical analysis and characterization
sections.text:
Microscopic investigation of the precursor PPy and NCs was carried out by a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, S-4800) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS)
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
and transmission electron microscopy (TEM; J M-2100, JEOL) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The structure was characterized using the X-ray diffraction (XRD, PAN-alytical, X’Pert PRO X diffractometer) with a Cu-Kα radiation (λ=0.15406 nm) by step scanning of 10 degree per minute. The chemical structure was ascertained by the Raman spectroscopy (HORIBA Jobin Yvon) with a 514 nm laser light and the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) measurement with an AXIS-ULTRA DLD (Al Ka X-ray source, 1486.60 eV). All binding energies of XPS were referenced to the C 1s neutral carbon peak set at 284.6 eV to compensate for surface charging effects. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at 77K with a BECKMAN COULTERAUT SA3100. The specific surface area was determined via the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the pore volume and pore size were determined via Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method and non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) method. The electronic conductivities of all NCs were measured by four point probe
resistivity meter (Guangzhou 4-probes Tect, RTS-9) at 23±1 ℃.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
The slurry of 80% as-prepared samples, 10% carbon black (Super-P) and 10% Poly(vinylidene fluoride) binder (PVDF) in N-methylpyrrolidone was coated on aluminium foil and dried at 50
℃ for 4 h and then dried at 110 ℃ overnight in vacuum oven to obtain the electrode with a loading of around 2.5±0.15 mg cm-2. The thickness of the electrodes of each sample is about 25 µm, as shown in Figure S1. The supercapacitors in 2-electrode configuration were performed in 1.5 M organic electrolyte MeEt3NBF4/PC (DLC307, Shenzhen Capchem Technology Co., Ltd.), and the test cells were assembled inMikrouna Super glove box under a dry argon atmosphere. Cyclic voltammetry (CV), galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) measurement were performed on the Versatile Multichannel Potentiostat 2/Z (VMP2, Princeton applied research) in the voltage range from 0 to 2.6 V. The cycling stability measurement was performed by the Arbin Battery Test System. The specific capacitance was calculated as 2It/(m∆U) by GCD curve, where I is the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
charge/discharge current, t is the discharging time, m is the mass of the active materials on single electrode, and ∆U stands for the potential window (after deduction of IR drop).

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
XRD patterns of the NCs samples are depicted in Figure 1a. Two broad diffraction peaks can be observed at 2θ values of around 26° and 43°, which can be assigned to (002) and (101) planes of hexagonal carbon material (JCPDS, Card No. 75-1621) [11], respectively. The broad peaks suggest that these NCs have an amorphous feature with a low degree of graphitic crystallinity. Nevertheless, the intensity of the peak at around 26° gradually increases with the carbonization temperature increasing, which indicates tiny improvement of the graphitization degree at higher temperatures. Moreover, the peak at around 43° also increases with the increase of carbonization temperature. This indicates the formation of a higher degree of intra-layer condensation which can improve the electronic conductivity of carbons [43]. The improvement of graphitization can be further demonstrated by Raman spectra. The two characteristic peaks in the Raman spectra of carbons are the so-called D and G band, which lie at about 1350 cm-1 and 1588 cm-1, respectively. The D band is due to the presence of disorder, and the G band is due to the graphite in-plane vibration of carbonaceous materials [44]. The ratio of D and G band (ID/IG ratio) can be used to evaluate the defects degree. And research groups usually used two Gaussians fit to report the ID/IG ratio of the peak area [45, 46]. Here, a simple symmetric Gaussians multipeak fit for the D and G band was used, and the fitted cures are shown in Figure S2. The full width at half maximum (FWHM) and ID/IG ratio of the peaks can be obtained based on these fitted data. For amorphous carbon, these two peaks FWHM broaden as the disorder increases, and the FWHM of D band increases much more than that of G band [46, 47]. As shown in Figure 1b, both the FWHM of the
D and G band decrease as the carbonization temperature increases from 500 ℃ to 900 ℃, and
the former decreases more obvious. It suggests that the disorder of the NCs decreases as
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
temperature increase. Moreover, the integral area ratio of ID/ G also decreases from 3.44 to 2.87 as the temperature increases from 500 ℃ to 900 ℃ (Table S1), indicating that less disorder takes place at higher temperature. It indicates that this carbon material has fewer defects and more sp2 sites [45].
Figure 1. (a) XRD patterns of all NCs, and (b) Raman spectra of all NCs and the FWHM of D-band and G-band calculated from Raman spectra.
Figure 2 shows SEM and TEM images of the precursor PPy and NC-900 sample. It can be seen that they both have obvious graphene-like sheet morphology, indicating that NC-900 retains the original nano-sheet structure of PPy after carbonization and activation. SEM images of all NCs (Figure S3) evidently show that the sheet size gradually becomes smaller with the increase of
carbonization temperature from 500 ℃ to 900 ℃. A simple scheme for preparation NCs is
shown in Figure 2a, and the sheet size of NCs strongly depends on the carbonization temperature.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
The reason is that burn-off and shrinkage of the PPy previous can be enhanced as the carbonization temperature increasing. Figure 2e shows TEM micrograph highlighting some thin NC-900 fragment resting on a holey carbon support. The fragment is thinner, rougher and more stretch, which may provide large surface area.
Figure 2. (a) Synthesis scheme for the preparation of NCs from PPy precursor, (b, c) SEM images of PPy precursor and NC-900, and (d, e) TEM images of PPy and NC-900.
Specific surface area (SSA) and porosity was analysed by nitrogen adsorption-desorption technique. As depicted in Figure 3a, the SSA of NC-900 calculated by the BET method is 1450 m2 g-1, which is almost 8 times of that of NC-500 (Table 1). The increase of SSA is mainly caused by mesoporous pores (>86%, by t-plot method [41, 48], as shown in Table S2) at the high active temperature. And the pore volume increasing is also mainly caused by mesoporous volume (Figure S4). High surface area can provide more active sites for ion electrostatic adsorption. And more mesopores can provide a more advantageous path for penetration and transportation of electrolyte ions. Moreover, the pore radius of NC-900 (Figure S4) is mainly distributed in 2-20 nm corresponding to the mesopores, which is easier for the electrolyte infiltration and ions exchange to facilitate good dynamic charge transportation.
M AN
US
CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
Figure 3. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of all the as-prepared NCs.
To analyze the elemental composition and bonding configurations, EDS and XPS was performed on the as-prepared NCs (Figure S5). Elemental analysis indicates that the content of C element increases from 64.2% of PPy to 92.8% of NC-900, and in contrast, the content of N and O decreases from 9.7% and 20.1 % to 2.8% and 4.4%, respectively. The same trend can be found by XPS analysis, where the N/C and O/C ratios decrease from 0.15 and 0.31 (PPy) to 0.028 and 0.13 (NC-900), respectively (Table S3). The result reveals that N and O element reduce more quickly during the carbonization and activation process because of the aromatization and dehydrogenation. In addition, the detailed deconvolution of N 1s region XPS spectrum (Figure 4) can be fitted by three component peaks located at 398.2±0.2 eV, 399.7±0.2 eV and 400.8±0.2eV, corresponding to three different environments: pyridinic N (N-6), pyrrolic/pyridine N (N-5) and quaternary N (N-Q), respectively [38, 49]. For PPy, the peak of 399.8 eV (N-5) and 401.2 eV (N+-5) is associated with benzenoid amine (-NH-) and protonation benzenoid amine (-NH+-) within the pentagonal PPy ring, and the ratio of the N+-5 depends on the doped degree [50]. After carbonization, two new peaks of N-6 and N-Q appear, and the N-5 peak becomes weak. As summarized in Table 1, it can be found that more of the nitrogen atoms are embedded into graphitic structure in the form of N-Q with the temperature increasing. The ratio of N-Q/N-6 increases from 0.97 (NC-500) to 3.56 (NC-900) indicating that N-Q is more stable than N-6 at
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
high temperature. More N-Q introduce can provide a stable donor doping and greatly improve the electronic conductivity of these carbon materials, which is also further demonstrated by the four-probe resistivity measurement (Table 1).
Figure 4. XPS N 1s spectra of PPy and all NCs sample.

Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) measurements were carried out to evaluate its electrochemical performance in a symmetrical two-electrode configuration with 1.5 M MeEt3NBF4/PC organic electrolyte in the voltage range from 0 to 2.6 V.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
As demonstrated in Figure 5, it can be found that the CV curve of NC-900 at the scan rate of 50 mV s-1 is closer to the rectangular shape with a large current response, suggesting well capacitive characteristics and large capacitance. As the scan rate is increased to 200 mV s-1 (Figure S6), the CV curve of NC-900 still shows a nearly rectangular shape, suggesting fast transfer of ions and electrons. However, these of the other NCs prepared at low temperature deviate from the rectangular shape, indicating a quick degradation of capacitance. Furthermore, the NC-900 electrodes can be operated at various scan rates up to 10 V s-1 (in which, the charge-discharge time is only 0.26 s) and the CV curves still keep the quasi-rectangular shape (Figure 5b). It should be noted that the value is 1-2 order of magnitude higher than many scan rates for the carbon electrodes measured even in aqueous electrolytes [30, 33, 34, 42, 50]. Specific capacitances (Cm) of 190 F g-1, 146 F g-1, 113 F g-1, 65 F g-1, and 25 F g-1 can be calculated from the CV curves for NC-900, NC-800, NC-700, NC-600, and NC-500 at the scan rate of 2 mV s-1, which retain 129 F g-1, 87 F g-1, 20 F g-1, 7.1 F g-1, and 1.2 F g-1 at 1000 mV s-1, respectively (Figure 5c). It can be seen that the NC-900 electrodes have the highest capacitance and best rate capability, which is likely attributed to both large specific surface area and the presence of N-Q species N-doping. This special N-Q species N-doping can improve electronic conductivity of carbon to insure the rapid and reversible ion/charge transfer and exchange. GCD measurements (Figure 5d) also show that NC-900 exhibits the largest charging/discharging time at the same current density of 2 A g-1, corresponding to the highest capacitance. The comparison of specific capacitances normalized by mass and BET surface area at different current densities from 0.5 to 8 A g-1 is shown in Figure 5e and Figure 5f, respectively. It can be seen that the gravimetric specific capacitance (Cm) significantly increase with the increase of activation temperature. The reason can be attributed to the large specific surface area obtained at high temperatures. On the other hand, the surface area normalized capacitances (Cs) of all NCs is near to 13-15 µF cm -2 at low current density of 0.5 A g-1. As the current density increases, NC-900 exhibits a good retention rate of the Cs (78% at 8 A
M
AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
g-1), which should be attributed to the low ion/charge transport resistance. In contrary, the Cs values of other NCs decrease significantly, and the retention rates are only 58.8%, 40.1%, 39.2%, and 33.7% at 8 A g-1 for NC-800, NC-700, NC-600, and NC-500, respectively.
Figure 5. (a) CV curves of all NCs at the scan rate of 50 mV s-1, (b) CV curves of NC-900 at high scan rates, (c) rate performance based on weight at different scan rate, (d) GCD cures of all NCs at 2 A g-1, and (e, f) gravimetric specific capacitance and BET area normalized specific capacitance of all NCs at different current densities.
Meanwhile, the Nyquist spectra of all NCs can be seen in Figure 6a, and the nearly vertical shape at low-frequency region of NC-900 indicates a good capacitive response behavior. The relationship between Zre and ɷ -1/2 at low frequency is seen in Figure 6b (An amplification figure at low Zre shown in Figure S7). When the ɷ-1/2 value is in the range from 0.2 to 2.5, the relationship can be fitted by a linear relationship, Zre =Rs+Rct+σw ɷ -1/2. The slope of the fitted line corresponds to the Warburg coefficient (σw). It is observed that the σw of NC-900, NC-800, NC-700, NC-600, and NC-500 is 1.5, 3.2, 5.6, 29.4, and 80.1 Ω cm2 s-1, respectively. The smallest σw of NC-900 indicates that the ion/charge can quickly diffuse and exchange at the electrode/electrolyte interface due to its good ion channels and high electronic
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
conductivity. On the other hand, Figure 6c presents the evolution of the imaginary part of the coplex capacitance (Cim) vs. the frequency. The values of Cim has a maximum at the frequency fR, which defines a time constant: τR=1/fR. This time constant is a quantitative measure of how fast the device can be charged and discharged reversibly. The lower the time constant, the faster the device is. The τR of NC-900, NC-800, and NC-700 (also given in Figure 6c) are equal to 2.9 s, 4.3 s, and 9.5 s, respectively, which are in well agreement with the results of the Warburg coefficient. And the capacitance vs. frequency dependence (Figure 6d) also shows the best charge propagation for NC-900 with capacitance about 170 F g-1 at the low frequency range. The results obtained by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy are in accordance those by CV and GCD measurement techniques.
Figure 6. (a) Nyquist spectra for capacitors based on all NCs, the inset is the amplification at high frequency range, (b) the relationship between Zre and ɷ -1/2 at low frequency, (c) evolution of the imaginary part of the complex capacitance vs. frequency, and (d) specific capacitances vs. frequency dependence of all NCs.
In addition, the rate capability and cycle stability of NC-900 were further investigated by GCD technique at different current densities (Figure 7). The GCD curves (Figure 7a and Figure S8a) exhibit nearly triangular shape with low IR drop at current densities from 1 A g-1 to 64 A g-1, suggesting high reversibility of a typical capacitor with rapid current-voltage response owing to its N-doping structure which could enhance the electronic conductivity. A high capacitance of 192 F g-1 can be obtained at 0.5 A
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
g-1 (Figure S8b), as well as high capacitance retention ratios of 96.2%, 96.8%, 97.1%, 98.2% and 96.5% can be observed after 1000 cycles test at different current densities of 2, 5, 10, 20 A g-1 and back to 2 A g-1, respectively (Figure 7b). After this 5000 cycles charging-discharging test, GCD technique was performed again to study the capacitance performance at different current densities. The specific capacitances commonly remain 91-95.6% of the initial values (Figure S8c), indicating excellent cycling stability. In addition, long-term cycling stability of the symmetric supercapacitors was further performed at a current density of 5 A g-1. The capacitance remains 91.1% of the initial capacitance after 20000 cycles, and still exists 79.7% capacitance retention even after 75000 cycles (Figure 7c), revealing an excellent cycling stability. All of these imply that NC-900 is a promising candidate for supercapacitor electrode materials due to its high capacitance, excellent rate capability and cycling stability.
Figure 7. Rate capability and Cycling stability of the NC-900 electrodes: (a) GCD curves at different current densities, (b) Cycle stability performance at 2 A g-1, 5 A g-1, 10 A g-1, and 20 A g-1, (c) long-term cycling life test at 5 A g-1 in the voltage range from 0 to 2.6 V of the 25 µm thick electrodes, and (d) GCD curves at 1 A g-1, (e) rate performance and (f) Ragone plots of the 25 µm, 48 µm, 67 µm thick electrodes.

US CR
IP T

ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
To further evaluate the electrochemical performance, three different thick electrodes (25 µm, 48 µm, 67 µm) were prepared to study the effect of electrodes thickness. The GCD curves of three electrodes at current densities of 1 A g-1 (Figure 7d) exhibit nearly triangular shape, suggesting high reversibility of a typical capacitor. When the electrochemical responses of three thick electrodes were compared (Figure 7e, f), not surprisingly, the specific capacitances decreased with increased thickness. And at the low current densities, the capacitance decrease was not obvious due to the accessibility to electrolyte ion. Moreover, the energy and power density of the supercapacitor were estimated for the GCD measurement. The gravimetric specific energy density (Em) and power density (Pm) are calculated by the equation (1) and (2):
= ×
× ∆ 3.6⁄ (1);
= × × ∆ ⁄ (2);
where Em is the energy density (Wh kg -1), Pm is the power density (W kg -1), Cm is the gravimetric specific capacitance (F g-1), ∆U is the operating voltage window (measured in volts and obtained from the discharge curve excluding the IR drop (Udrop), ∆U=U-Udrop), ∆t is the discharge time (s), and m is the mass of the active materials on two electrodes (g). Ragone plot for NC-900 based supercapacitor is presented in Figure 7f. For 25 µm thick electrode, highest energy density of 45.2 Wh kg-1 can be delivered at power density of 260 W kg-1. With the increase of power density, the energy density slightly decreases. Even at high-power density of 38.7 kW kg-1, the energy density is still up to 23.3 Wh kg-1. On the other hand, the energy density has a comparatively good retention as the electrode thickness increase, especially at low current density. These values are relatively superior in comparison with some other carbon-based symmetric supercapacitor in organic electrolytes [28, 40, 51], which can be attributed to: (1) large specific surface area and adaptive pore structure which can provide more active sites and enhance ion/charge fast transport/exchange, and (2) N-Q type nitrogen doping of carbon can improve electronic
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
conductivity, and (3) mesopores can modify surface tension of the electrolyte and then improve surface wettability of the electrode materials.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we have fabricated a series of porous nitrogen-doped carbon nano-sheets (NCs) derived from polypyrrole precursor at different carbonization and activation temperatures from
500 to 900 ℃. The type of N atom turn from N-5 and N-6 turn to the more stable type of N-Q at
higher temperatures. This type of N atom (N-Q) locates inside graphite layers, which can provide a stable donor doping and greatly improve the electronic conductivity of the NCs. It can also be found that both of BET specific surface area (from 187 to 1450 m2 g-1) and pore volume (from 0.082 to 0.99 cm-3 g-1) are near linearly increasing with the increase of activation temperature, and higher temperatures lead to the increase of mesoporous volume with 5-20 nm in radius. Such high electronic conductivity, high surface area and appropriate mesoporous size distribution are the key factors to obtain superior electrochemical performance as supercapacitor electrode materials. In the symmetric capacitor configuration, the synthesized NC-900 demonstrates high specific capacitance of 192 F g-1 in 1.5 M EtMe3NBF4/PC organic electrolyte at 0.5 A g -1, which can retain 130 F g-1 at 40 A g-1. Good rate performance, excellent cycling stability (less than 9% degradation after 20000 cycles at 5 A g-1), high energy density (45.2 Wh kg-1) and large power density (up to 38.7 kW kg-1).

referenceMentions.context: 2 High performance energy storage devices are one of the most important elements for the future development of portable electronic devices, electrical vehicles and renewable energy [1].
It has been demonstrated that the supercapacitor performances crucially depend on the physical and chemical properties of its electrode materials [2, 3].
It has been demonstrated that the supercapacitor performances crucially depend on the physical and chemical properties of its electrode materials [2, 3].
Pseudo-capacitance electrodes are based on the fast and reversible redox reaction at the surface or near-surface of the active materials [4, 5].

Battery-like electrodes usually use traditional battery materials which can exhibit capacitance-like properties at nanoscale dimensions due to the fast ion intercalation and diffusion (usually is Li) [4, 6].
According to the reports in recent years, conducting polymers [7, 8] and metal oxides [9] show great potential as the supercapacitors electrode material due to their large faraday pseudo-capacitance.
According to the reports in recent years, conducting polymers [7, 8] and metal oxides [9] show great potential as the supercapacitors electrode material due to their large faraday pseudo-capacitance.
According to the reports in recent years, conducting polymers [7, 8] and metal oxides [9] show great potential as the supercapacitors electrode material due to their large faraday pseudo-capacitance.

Nevertheless, carbon based materials (about 80-120 F g in organic electrolytes) are still the dominant electrode material for commercial supercapacitors because of their high electronic conductivity, low cost, long cycling life, suitability to various electrolyte systems including organic electrolytes, and higher stability (long-time and potential dependent) [3, 10].

Although most of porous carbon materials exhibit a large capacitance due to their large specific surface area, the electronic conductivity decreased with further increasing specific surface area and porosity due to non-compatibility of conductive pathways, which significantly limits the rate performance and power capability[12, 29].

To date, there are two common strategies utilized to incorporate nitrogen atoms into carbon materials: (1) post treatment of the porous carbon with nitrogen rich reagents such as urea [36], ammonia [37], and nitrogen gas [38]; (2) in situ doping by carbonizing nitrogen-rich synthetic polymers or organic carbon precursors [11, 12, 39-41], such as polyacrylonitrile [39], formaldehyde resins [40], and egg white [41].

metadata.abstractText: Porous yet high electronic conductivity carbon electrodes with high ion-adsorptive surface area and low ion/charge transport resistance are crucial to the realization of high-energy/power supercapacitors but have proved to be very challenging to obtain. Herein, nitrogen-doped nano-sheet carbons were synthesized by direct carbonization and activation of polypyrrole at different temperatures. As the temperature increases from 500 to 900 °C, the specific surface area increases from 187 m g to 1450 m g with abundant mesopore and the doping-nitrogen transfer to more stable donor doping state which can improve its electronic conductivity (up to 26.2 S cm). Symmetrical supercapacitors based on this carbon exhibit a high energy density of 45.0 Wh kg at 260 W kg and 22.3 Wh kg as the power density increasing to 38.7 kW kg, as well as excellent long-term cycling stability, which can be ascribed to its high surface area for electrolyte ions adsorption, and abundant mesopore and high electronic conductivity for ion and electron fast transfer. The remarkable performances suggest that this carbon material is a promising candidate for high-power output supercapacitor electrode materials.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
